summary: Gwen Stefani saying she wants Brie Larson to play her in a biopic if they make one is just like... yes??? We already know she...
body: Gwen Stefani saying she wants Brie Larson to play her in a biopic if they make one is just like… yes??? We already know she can belt some No Doubt like a champ and the thought of her dressing like Gwen is just the best. Imagine Brie in this outfit… I would swoon.

summary: Honestly, if I was Brie Larson, I’d be fucking smug about all these nerd boiiis hating me. It would just fuel me even more. If...
body: Honestly, if I was Brie Larson, I’d be fucking smug about all these nerd boiiis hating me. It would just fuel me even more. If you’re not making sexist assholes angry at some point, then you’re probably doing something wrong. Ya know?

summary: If Captain Marvel has a mission statement, this scene is it. It’s set up like a classic Mexican stand-off. Carol and Yon-Rogg...
caption:
If Captain Marvel has a mission statement, this scene is it.

It’s set up like a classic Mexican stand-off. Carol and Yon-Rogg are shot in mirror. It’s a dusty desert field in the western United States. You can almost hear Ennio Morricone on the soundtrack, right? But there’s an imbalance to the scene from the beginning. 

Yon-Rogg and Captain Marvel are not even remotely matched in pound-for-pound combat ability. Put simply, she could wipe the floor with him in an instant. There are a lot of people who are media illiterate and think she should have fought Yon-Rogg on his terms, in hand-to-hand combat without the use of her photon blasts, but this isn’t that kind of movie.

Yes, the theme is spelled out more explicitly a couple of minutes later, but film is a visual medium and this sequence–Carol approaching Yon-Rogg, who is clearly still full of unearned self-confidence–is a brilliant visual representation of it. It comes down to this: this is not a movie about living up to other’s expectations. It’s about becoming who you are.

Captain Marvel’s a tripartite character, and the film is structured as a series of interlocking origin stories building towards the third act moment of becoming. She’s Carol Danvers, the adventurous young girl who became USAF pilot. She’s Vers, duped into helping the Kree Starforce in their genocidal mission. Slowly we learn who each of these people were. And now, finally, she’s let go of the chains of both and embraced the best of either. 

She’s Captain Marvel–Carol’s humanity married to Vers’ power, unleashed by self-actualisation. In understanding who Carol was, who Vers was and finally what she’s capable of being, she becomes a whole person.

Yon-Rogg did not make her the best version of herself as he claimed. The Supreme Intelligence did not shape her into anything but a shadow of itself. No one made Captain Marvel. Carol Danvers and Vers and Captain Marvel are just like everyone else: a product of this one woman’s character, her choices and her circumstances.

It just so happens that hers have conspired to make her Earth’s mightiest hero.

Captain Marvel is not a perfect movie, but damn if it isn’t trying to say something. It’s aspiring to be more than a superhero punch-up and that’s to be applauded.

summary:
Genre: fluff, LGBTQ+
Warnings: hella domestic gays, Brie being too fuckin precious, some cursing
Words: 663
Prompt: I’ve seen...
body:
HOME SWEET HOME

Genre: fluff, LGBTQ+

Warnings: hella domestic gays, Brie being too fuckin precious, some cursing

Words: 663

Prompt: I’ve seen Captain Marvel twice and both times were just two hours of Gay Panic™️


“Brie! Where’s the cat food?” You called from the kitchen, crouched in front of the cupboard. Freddie, your male calico cat, rubbed against your leg.

“I thought it was in the pantry.” She said coming out of your bedroom, her ponytail coming undone at the crown of her head.

“No,” you rose from the crouch,

“We’d run out of it. I texted you and you said you’d pick some up.” The color in your girlfriend’s face drained.

“Shit, I’m so sorry babe. I completely forgot.”

“Brie, it’s not a big deal. I’ll just go and grab some real quick.”

“No. I forgot it, I’ll go.” She intercepted you, pinning your hand that had your car keys to the counter with her own.

“Brie-“ You started, but you didn’t have the time to form the argument because she pressed her lips against yours, slowly slipping your keys from under your fingers.

“Sorry, sweets, I’ll be back with cat food.” She kissed your nose, scrunched incredulously and out the door she breezed. After a minute of staring stupidly at the door, you called Brie.

“That was not fair.” She laughed on the other end.

“I’m sorry, darling. I didn’t want to make extra work for you because I fucked up.”

“It wasn’t a problem, seriously.”

“Whatever, I’m in the parking lot of the store now.”

“Alright. See you in a bit.” She made a kissing sound at the phone before hanging up. You rolled your eyes and set it down back on the counter. Freddie rubbed against your leg.

“She’ll be back soon, bub.” You lifted the hefty calico into your arms.

“You’re getting fat, buddy.” He purred quietly.

“But you knew that didn’t you?” You sat at the counter holding Freddie in your lap, waiting for Brie’s keys, well, your keys in Brie’s hand, to rattle the door knob. When the knob finally rattled, Freddie jumped down from your arms and sat a few feet in front of the door, eagerly winding between Brie’s ankles when the door swung open.

“Hey, handsome! Did you know I had food?” The cat meowed impatiently.

“I’ll take that as a yes.” Brie set the grocery bag on the counter and gave you a kiss on the cheek.

“The hunter home from the hunt.” You smiled.

“Yep. Wasn’t that so much easier?” You rolled your eyes.

“It would have gotten done no matter who did it.” You retort, wrinkling your nose at her.

“Yes But you asked me to do something and I didn’t do it. It’s the principle of the thing.”

“Brie, you just got home from a six month press tour, which you only had about a week at home to rest up from filming a movie before that. You’re tired and probably jet lagged, if you forget stuff, especially cat food for crying out loud, I’m not gonna be upset at all. You know that right?”

“Yeah.” Brie nodded.

“You finish unpacking and I’ll feed the beast.” You kissed her cheek and grabbed the cat food, Freddie following you excitedly.

“C’mon fatty.” Brie went back to the shared bedroom and fished through her suitcase to put the rest of her things away. You made your way into the room and hugged her from behind.

“Fed the beast.”

“Good.”

“Need any help?”

“You can take the basket of dirty clothes to the laundry room.” She ruffled your hair with one hand while continuing to sort through the suitcase. You took the basket, dropped it in front of the washer and made your way back to the bedroom, where Brie was putting her suitcase back in the closet.

“I’m now officially back.” She announced before tackling you onto the bed.

“I missed you.” She whispered against your neck.

“I missed you too, superhero.”
body_abstract:
HOME SWEET HOME

Genre: fluff, LGBTQ+

Warnings: hella domestic gays, Brie being too fuckin precious, some cursing

Words: 663

Prompt: I’ve seen Captain Marvel twice and both times were just two hours of Gay Panic™️


“Brie! Where’s the cat food?” You called from the kitchen, crouched in front of the cupboard. Freddie, your male calico cat, rubbed against your leg.

“I thought it was in the pantry.” She said coming out of your bedroom, her ponytail coming undone at the crown of her head.

“No,” you rose from the crouch,

“We’d run out of it. I texted you and you said you’d pick some up.” The color in your girlfriend’s face drained.

“Shit, I’m so sorry babe. I completely forgot.”

“Brie, it’s not a big deal. I’ll just go and grab some real quick.”

“No. I forgot it, I’ll go.” She intercepted you, pinning your hand that had your car keys to the counter with her own.

“Brie-“ You started, but you didn’t have the time to form the argument because she pressed her lips against yours, slowly slipping your keys from under your fingers.

“Sorry, sweets, I’ll be back with cat food.” She kissed your nose, scrunched incredulously and out the door she breezed. After a minute of staring stupidly at the door, you called Brie.

“That was not fair.” She laughed on the other end.

“I’m sorry, darling. I didn’t want to make extra work for you because I fucked up.”

“It wasn’t a problem, seriously.”

“Whatever, I’m in the parking lot of the store now.”

“Alright. See you in a bit.” She made a kissing sound at the phone before hanging up. You rolled your eyes and set it down back on the counter. Freddie rubbed against your leg.

“She’ll be back soon, bub.” You lifted the hefty calico into your arms.

“You’re getting fat, buddy.” He purred quietly.

“But you knew that didn’t you?” You sat at the counter holding Freddie in your lap, waiting for Brie’s keys, well, your keys in Brie’s hand, to rattle the door knob. When the knob finally rattled, Freddie jumped down from your arms and sat a few feet in front of the door, eagerly winding between Brie’s ankles when the door swung open.

“We’d run out of it. I texted you and you said you’d pick some up.” The color in your girlfriend’s face drained.

“Shit, I’m so sorry babe. I completely forgot.”

“Brie, it’s not a big deal. I’ll just go and grab some real quick.”

“No. I forgot it, I’ll go.” She intercepted you, pinning your hand that had your car keys to the counter with her own.

“Brie-“ You started, but you didn’t have the time to form the argument because she pressed her lips against yours, slowly slipping your keys from under your fingers.

“Sorry, sweets, I’ll be back with cat food.” She kissed your nose, scrunched incredulously and out the door she breezed. After a minute of staring stupidly at the door, you called Brie.

“That was not fair.” She laughed on the other end.

“I’m sorry, darling. I didn’t want to make extra work for you because I fucked up.”

“It wasn’t a problem, seriously.”

“Whatever, I’m in the parking lot of the store now.”

“Alright. See you in a bit.” She made a kissing sound at the phone before hanging up. You rolled your eyes and set it down back on the counter. Freddie rubbed against your leg.

“She’ll be back soon, bub.” You lifted the hefty calico into your arms.

“You’re getting fat, buddy.” He purred quietly.

“But you knew that didn’t you?” You sat at the counter holding Freddie in your lap, waiting for Brie’s keys, well, your keys in Brie’s hand, to rattle the door knob. When the knob finally rattled, Freddie jumped down from your arms and sat a few feet in front of the door, eagerly winding between Brie’s ankles when the door swung open.

[[MORE]]

“Hey, handsome! Did you know I had food?” The cat meowed impatiently.

“I’ll take that as a yes.” Brie set the grocery bag on the counter and gave you a kiss on the cheek.

“The hunter home from the hunt.” You smiled.

“Yep. Wasn’t that so much easier?” You rolled your eyes.

“It would have gotten done no matter who did it.” You retort, wrinkling your nose at her.

“Yes But you asked me to do something and I didn’t do it. It’s the principle of the thing.”

“Brie, you just got home from a six month press tour, which you only had about a week at home to rest up from filming a movie before that. You’re tired and probably jet lagged, if you forget stuff, especially cat food for crying out loud, I’m not gonna be upset at all. You know that right?”

“Yeah.” Brie nodded.

“You finish unpacking and I’ll feed the beast.” You kissed her cheek and grabbed the cat food, Freddie following you excitedly.

“C’mon fatty.” Brie went back to the shared bedroom and fished through her suitcase to put the rest of her things away. You made your way into the room and hugged her from behind.

“Fed the beast.”

“Good.”

“Need any help?”

“You can take the basket of dirty clothes to the laundry room.” She ruffled your hair with one hand while continuing to sort through the suitcase. You took the basket, dropped it in front of the washer and made your way back to the bedroom, where Brie was putting her suitcase back in the closet.

“I’m now officially back.” She announced before tackling you onto the bed.

“I missed you.” She whispered against your neck.

“I missed you too, superhero.”
trail.content:

Warnings: hella domestic gays, Brie being too fuckin precious, some cursing

Prompt: I’ve seen Captain Marvel twice and both times were just two hours of Gay Panic™️

“C’mon fatty.” Brie went back to the shared bedroom and fished through her suitcase to put the rest of her things away. You made your way into the room and hugged her from behind.

“Fed the beast.”

“Good.”

“You can take the basket of dirty clothes to the laundry room.” She ruffled your hair with one hand while continuing to sort through the suitcase. You took the basket, dropped it in front of the washer and made your way back to the bedroom, where Brie was putting her suitcase back in the closet.

summary: “The core?”  “The woman.”  When you go back to the stars and tell others of this planet—when you tell them of its riches, its...
caption:
“The core?”

“The woman.”

When you go back to the stars and tell others of this planet—when you tell them of its riches, its people, its potential— when you talk of the Earth. Then make sure that you tell them this:

It is defended.

summary: I wasn't perfect and didn't have it together. I felt alone. So through acting, I decided to be a shape shifter and with every...
caption: I wasn’t perfect and didn’t have it together. I felt alone. So through acting, I decided to be a shape shifter and with every role become the character instead of being myself. It meant about 10 years of no one knowing I was the same person in every movie.
